title: preston-lodge-high-school-supporting-need-christmas
story: One of the appeals has seen the school organise its annual lsquoreverse Advent calendarrsquo.Typically, Advent calendars see people open one door a day in the countdown to Christmas Day and receive a treat, such as chocolate or a beauty item.However, Preston Lodgersquos reverse Advent calendar sees people give items rather than receive them.Pupils and their families are being encouraged to donate food items which will be given to East Lothian Sunday Fresh Chicken Dinner Boxes.The initiative was set up by Prestonpans resident Jane Russell last Christmas and delivers food boxes to people most in need across East Lothian.Each box contains meat, fresh vegetables, sauces, spices, sides, dessert and a recipe card, allowing struggling families to eat a fresh meal.In the process of becoming a charity, the initiative has been supported by some famous faces, including Prestonpansrsquo world champion boxer Josh Taylor, who took time out in May to help volunteers pack dinner kits.In April, he also helped Jane and the Easter Bunny deliver Easter eggs to local children.The school said it was ldquooverwhelmed with the support its reverse Advent calendar had received over the past couple of years.People are being asked to donate festive food items which will go towards the causersquos Christmas dinner boxes, allowing people to enjoy a three-course, fresh Christmas dinner.The cut-off point for referrals is Tuesday, with people asked to email christmasdinnerboxes@gmailFood items that can be delivered include shortbread, mince pies, turkey gravy granules, table crackers, small boxes of chocolate, boxes of biscuits, hot chocolate, squirty cream, Christmas cake, ham stock cubes, tinfoil and oatcakes.Meanwhile, Preston Lodgersquos other venture is supporting Womenrsquos Aid.The school is collecting items such as toiletries, sanitary products and toothbrushes which will all be donated to the Womenrsquos Aid East Lothian and Midlothian branch.In its weekly newsletter PLus, the school said: ldquoThey [Womenrsquos Aid] were very grateful for our donations last year.ldquoThe Christmas period is a time when domestic violence increases and many women have to flee their homes without basic provisions.Pupils should hand in all donations to the school office.

title: retired-musselburgh-journalist-george-campbell-cunningham-publishes-first-book
story: George Campbell Cunningham, , of Greenfield Park, Monktonhall, is a former convener of Tyne and Esk Writers, and features an ldquoeclectic mix of  short stories in his publication Her Holiness The Pope.He said: ldquoSome are slightly thought-provoking while others have a sting in the tail others are simply funny.Mr Cunningham said: ldquoI was idly scrolling through some computer files one day when I came across a couple of short stories I had written some time ago and forgotten about, so I set about finding how many others there were.ldquoSome were only half written, other were just outline ideas and most needed a complete re-write.ldquoSo I set about editing and in some cases just taking the theme and producing a new version.Although fictional, some of the stories are set in real historical events.Mr Cunningham, a former pupil of the Royal High School in Edinburgh, said his stories ranged ldquofrom seeing great events through the eyes of those who were there to antics in a government press office that brings central London grinding to a halt, adding: ldquoOne story records the exchange between a husband and we at a funeral tea and raises, in a humorous way, whether a flat cap is a bunnet or a hat!ldquoAt one time, there were a number of magazines on bookstalls made up of short stories and were ideal for people who were commuting. In some small way, I hope this book helps fill the gap.Mr Cunningham has always wanted to write from an early age and went on to become a trainee journalist on the Scottish .He said: ldquoI was brought up in a family that enjoyed reading books so that became my inspiration.ldquoI became a journalist thinking that might be the route to writing novels ndash but I was wrong. Thinking like a journalist does not really make creative writing easy.ldquoTo help me make the transition, I joined the Musselburgh group of Tyne and Esk Writers and that became my launch pad to creative writing.ldquoAlthough I left school with no real qualications, I discovered early in my association that Glasgow University ran a Master of Letters degree course by distanced learning and, on the basis of my CV and samples of my writing, I was admitted to the course ndash all thanks to Tyne and Esk Writers.He added: ldquoAs the world of newspapers began to shrink, I joined the Government Information Servicein Edinburgh, ending my association with the GIS as a spokesman for the Royal Air Force in Scotland.ldquoI then ventured into the world of commercial PR, eventually setting up on my own. I loved digging out offbeat articles for my clientsrsquo activities.ldquoFor me, observation is an essential skill for anyone wanting to be a creative writer ndash along, of course, with a vivid imagination.For more information and to order a signed copy, send your details to stillwriting now@gmail

title: musselburgh-couple-brought-together-love-rock-roll-celebrate-diamond-wedding-anniversary
story: The couple, from Musselburgh, have been ldquooverwhelmed by the kindness from well-wishers who sent cards to mark their diamond wedding.The icing on the cake was a card from the Queen which will be put in an anniversary frame, which they received as a gt, and have pride of place on the wall of their home on Galt Road.Andrew, , known as Drew, and Marica, , were born and brought up in Musselburgh.They met at the local dancing that was on every Saturday evening at Stoneyhill Community Centre.Both shared a love of rock and roll, and loved to jive together.Their relationship blossomed and they were married at Loretto Chapel on Newbigging, on November , .Drew, an apprentice joiner, was  and Marica, a wig maker, was  when they tied the knot.The couple started married le together staying at Drewrsquos grandmotherrsquos home on Eskview Road, Musselburgh. They lived there for a few months before moving into their own home on the townrsquos Campie Road.The couple have four children ndash Gillian, Ian, Paula and Mark. They are now , ,  and  years old.Drew and Marica now have six granddaughters, seven great grandchildren, and their first great, great grandchild arrived in March.The family have been through a dficult year, as Drew was taken into hospital on March  and tested positive for Covid-. He ed home on May .Daughter Gillian said: ldquoIt was an extremely worrying time for the whole family indeed. Dad is now making good progress in his recovery.ldquoSadly, all the family couldnrsquot enjoy their special day with them due to Covid restrictions but hope still to go ahead with a big family lunch next year to celebrate.The couple said the main crux of their long and happy marriage was that ldquono matter what happens in le,you work through it together and have love for each other and around you, thatrsquos all that matters.ldquoLove conquers all! they stressed.Gillian added: ldquoMum and dad are truly our king and queen of our family and we couldnrsquot be prouder of them both.

title: young-peoples-support-group-heavy-sound-raising-5-000-christmas-campaign
story: Heavy Sound, a community interest company, works with those aged  to  who are not engaged with the education system or who are in care and have been referred by Childrenrsquos Hearings Scotland.The youngsters might be struggling with the education system or live in a traumatic household with parents who cannot look after themselves or their children.Heavy Sound, launched by Jordan Butler, who himself experienced extreme hardship as a teenager, runs music and sports projects to teach skills and build confidence.A spokeswoman for Heavy Sound said: ldquoWe get referrals through social work and through education systems, the high schools.ldquoWersquove got computers, a skills lab where people can do all sorts of learning ndash arithmetic and writing -- talk about education and jobs, but we also have a huge space which wersquove turned into a gym, and we have a recording studio.A typical day with the group, which moved from its office in Tranent to Cockenzie Business Hub, might see a teenager learning the martial art Muay Thai in the gym having a one-to-one discussion with a coach on fitness, healthy eating and avoiding conflict and taking part in a music session DJing, writing lyrics and producing tracks on state-of-the-art recording equipment.Throughout the day, youngsters also have the opportunity to take part in their choice of activities, including bike maintenance, bike rides and creative arts such as expressive art spray painting.The group also operates the Community Reach  Inclusion Bus , a single-decker bus which has been turned into a mobile recording studio and music lab, and visits schools and areas of deprivation.During lockdown, when young people were unable to join the group projects, Heavy Sound delivered , weekly food parcels, made  bulk community kitchen deliveries and , shopping deliveries, and distributed , lunch bags and meals throughout East Lothian and Edinburgh.The spokeswoman said: ldquoThe total cost of funding a young personrsquos day at Heavy Sound is pound..ldquoOur hope is that, by raising pound,, we will enable another  sessions to be experienced by those who need it the most.ldquoOur work highlights the fact that having one positive and trusted relationship in a young personrsquos le can be all they need to go on and achieve what might seem like the impossible.To donate to the Heavy Sound Christmas fund, go to crowdfunder pay-for-a-day-at-heavy-sound

title: darren-eales-gets-eight-year-sport-ban-second-doping-violation
story: UK Anti-Dopingcollected an in-competition urine sample from Darren Eales on February , , after a match between his Prestonpans-based team Preston Lodge and Dumfries Saints.Analysis of Mr Ealesrsquo A sample ed an adverse analytical findingfor stanozolol, an anabolic steroid that is derived from testosterone. The drug is used to enhance performance and is prohibited from sport at all times under the  WADA Prohibited List.Speaking on the case, Pat Myhill, UKADrsquos director of operations, said: ldquoThe decision to ban Mr Eales from sport for eight years shows the serious consequences of repeated attempts to cheat."The World Anti-Doping Code provides longer bans for second offences and this is a clear message that repeated cheating will not be tolerated.A UKAD statement said: "The case was referred by UKAD to the National Anti-Doping Panelin July last year."After affording Mr Eales numerous extensions, the NADP eventually imposed an eight-year ban last month after determining the case on the papers."Mr Eales did not provide any evidence to very his claim that he had used a contaminated supplement."Taking into consideration his provisional suspension, Mr Eales ban started on February , , and will expire at midnight on February , ."A Scottish Rugby spokesperson said: ldquoScottish Rugby takes a zero-tolerance approach to any use of prohibited substances to enhance performance."Theof this sanction, at eight years for a second doping offence, is welcomed as a warning to others and ensures Mr Eales will not be able to play rugby again until .ldquoEven though the playing season across Scotland has been curtailed by the Covid- pandemic, there is still the same anti-doping policies and measures in place, and we encourage any feedback from within the rugby communitythere is suspicion of anyone using illegal products.

title: martin-stephen-thanks-dunbar-rnli-lifeboat-crew-saved-life-50-years-ago
story: Martin Stephen , now , owes his le to the courage of David Brunton who, despite not being a strong swimmer, jumped into the treacherous swell as Martin sank unconscious beneath the waves.Martin StephenMartin said: ldquoI had been face down in the water for several minutes and was told later that Mr Brunton ed in fully clothed as I started to sink.Martin had found himself in trouble after trying and failing to rescue his -year-old cousin, David Jeffrey, who had been swept off the rocks at the entrance to Dunbar Harbour by a freak wave just two days before Christmas in .Sadly, young Davidrsquos body could not be found.When the leboat reached Martin, volunteer David, brother of then leboat coxswain Robert George Brunton, grabbed Martin by the hair and managed to raise his head above the surface.In the bitingly cold water, David began to struggle and a second crew member, Jonathan Alston, went overboard to assist.Using a throwing line and breeches belt, the rest of the crew hauled both volunteers and Martin aboard the Margaret leboat, where second coxswain Alexander Wilson performed mouth-to-mouth resuscitation and managed to get Martin breathing.He then took it in turns with assistant mechanic Andrew Smith to keep Martin alive until they could get him ashore.The Dunbar crew from , many of whom were still volunteering four years later when tragedy struck. From left: Charlie Smith, lsquoFuzzrsquo Davies, lsquoTeedie Lees, Jonathan lsquoJonahrsquo Alston. Alexander lsquoZanderrsquo Wilson, Coxswain Robert George Brunton and mechanic Bill Windram. Photo: Dunbar RNLIAs the th anniversary of that dramatic rescue approaches, Martin has written to Dunbar RNLI Leboat crewrsquos current coxswain, Gary Fairbairn.He said: ldquoIrsquove had  years of the happiest possible marriage, three sons and five grandchildren.ldquoAll in all Irsquove been able to live a wonderful le, but only because of the bravery of one man, the skill of another and the dedication and courage of the crew of the Dunbar leboat.ldquoI owe you everything. with his we Jenny, their three sons and their families, who wouldnrsquot be here were it not for the bravery of David Brunton and the Dunbar Leboat crew. From left: Rachelawith his we Jenny, their three sons and their families, who wouldnrsquot be here were it not for the bravery of David Brunton and the Dunbar Leboat crew. From left: Rachela Martin Stephenwith his we Jenny, their three sons and their families, who wouldnrsquot be here were it not for the bravery of David Brunton and the Dunbar Leboat crew. From left: Rachela Martin Stephenwith his we Jenny, their three sons and their families, who wouldnrsquot be here were it not for the bravery of David Brunton and the Dunbar Leboat crew. From left: Rachela , Raffie, Neill , Florence, Jenny , Henry , Martin, Leo, Becksand Harry . Seated: Jo , Immy, Simon . Photo: Martin StephenMartin, then a -year-old student in Sheffield, had been in Dunbar visiting his aunt, Maeve Jeffrey, of Biel Grange Farm, and had gone with cousins David and Angus, , to watch as the storm force northerly wind sent waves as high as  metres crashing over the harbour wall ndash something they had done countless times before.ldquoWe were standing at the mouth of the harbour when a freak wave came over, caught Davie and smashed him against the rocks, knocking him into the water, Martin recalled.ldquoI hadnrsquot even realised he had been standing higher up on the rocks. As soon as I saw him, I jumped in and managed to reach him.ldquoI held him in the rescue position but we kept going under. I think he was already dead.ldquoWe were in about a ft swell and kept going under. We were in the water for about  minutes.ldquoI pushed him back up, hoping the air in his jacket would keep him afloat but he kept sinking.ldquoI took off my wellies and jacket and kept swimming but could feel the hypothermia start to set in. My fingers and feet were numb.ldquoMy body was aching because Irsquod hit some rocks while jumping in. I was convinced I was dead but I kept swimming.ldquoI thought of my fianceacutee Jenny and her being told that Irsquod died. I wanted to tell her that death didnrsquot hurt. Thatrsquos when I lost consciousness.While Martin was desperately trying to save David, his cousin Angus raised the alarm.In four minutes, the ft Watson class Margaret was steaming from its moorings.RNLB Watson class Margaret leboat used to rescue Martin, which was in service in Dunbar from  to .It quickly arrived on scene, guided by fishermen who were on lookout from the rocks, including Davie Kittrick, who today serves as a deputy launch authority for the leboat.Davie said: ldquoThe leboat was having dficulty getting alongside because of the heavy swell.Martinrsquos unconscious body was barely visible above the water but David spotted him thanks to his bright blue shirt.For his courage, David was awarded the RNLI Bronze Medal for Gallantry and Jonathan Alston the Institutionrsquos Thanks on Vellum.Remarkably, David was not officially a member of the crew but, as an experienced fishing boat skipper, he was frequently called upon to join the leboat team.Over the years, the Brunton family produced three coxswains for Dunbar and, at one stage, six Brunton brothers were all volunteering with the crew.The six Brunton brothers who, at one stage all served on the crew. From left: Bob Marr, the brothersrsquo uncle, with Robert George, David, Peter, William, Jimmy and Ralph. Photo: Dunbar RNLIMartin, a retired headteacher and writer, asked to be put in touch with David Bruntonrsquos family so he could thank them personally.He wrote: ldquoI also wanted your volunteers to know just how lasting their work can be.Coxswain Gary admitted to feeling a ldquolump in his throat on reading the letter and shared its contents with the crew and other station volunteers, who were equally moved by the touching sentiment.Although both David and Robert George have since sadly passed away, Gary was able to put Martin in touch with Davidrsquos son Jamie, who still lives in the town.Jamie, , a retired engineer, said: ldquoI am very proud of my dad and what he did.ldquoGrowing up, dadrsquos commendation plaque for the rescue was on the wall in our living room but, although we asked him about it, my dad never spoke of it.David Bruntonrsquos bronze medalldquoBeing young, I have very little memory of the day other than it was not a normal day as dad came home soaking wet.ldquoI also remember being sent to answer our door when the press arrived and telling them dad had nothing to say.ldquoIt was a surprise to his children ndash we never saw our father in the water during our youth and assumed he couldnrsquot swim.ldquoIt wasnrsquot until we were adults and had children of our own that we saw him swim.ldquoMy brother and sister confirmed dad never spoke of the rescue.ldquoI think his attitude was lsquothatrsquos what the leboat does and the crew dorsquo, knowing full well as someone who loved the sea that his le could also be dependent on the RNLI one day.ldquoI donrsquot think I really understood the risks the RNLI take and the dangers the crew face and how dad had saved a manrsquos le at great risk to his own until Martin got in touch to tell me his story. Martin said he would not have had a wonderful le, three sons and five grandchildrenwas not for the RNLI and my dad.ldquoOur eldest son, named David after his grandfather, now holds the medals he was awarded, along with his framed letter of commendation.ldquoAll of his grandchildren are fascinated by their grandfatherrsquos story and his youngest grandson, Christopher, hopes toto Dunbar in the near future and wishes to join the leboat crew,possible, to keep the Brunton tradition alive., with his sons Davidand Christopher and their grandfatherrsquos bronze medal for bravery and the Institutionrsquos Thanks on Vellum. Photo: Nick Mailer" alt"East Lothian Courier: David Bruntonrsquos proud son Jamie , with his sons Davidand Christopher and their grandfatherrsquos bronze medal for bravery and the Institutionrsquos Thanks on Vellum. Photo: Nick Mailer" class"editor-image"David Bruntonrsquos proud son Jamie , with his sons Davidand Christopher and their grandfatherrsquos bronze medal for bravery and the Institutionrsquos Thanks on Vellum. Photo: Nick MailerMartin said: ldquoAs a result of my experience, I wanted to help people and make a dference.He became a teacher, then headmaster at The Perse School, Cambridge, and one of only two people to have been High Master at both Manchester Grammar and St Paulrsquos in London.He now lives in Norfolk and has survived heart surgery, cancer and a stroke.Despite those scares, the events of  are never far from his thoughts.He said his aunt Maeve, an active member of the Ladies Leboat Guild before she died, refused to blame him for the tragedy.Martin said: ldquoShe said we were in the wrong place at the wrong time.He used to ring her on December  every year.ldquoWe never mentioned Davie but she knew why I was ringing. Now on December  I shall be on the phone to Angus, who called the Coastguard and also saved my le.ldquoI imagine wersquoll not mention Davie but wersquoll know why I am ringing.And he added: ldquoI go back to Dunbar very regularly because we are still very close to the family and the forgiveness from the family has been one of the crucial things that allowed me to keep on living.ldquoEvery time I go back, I go near to that spot in the harbour and I say sorry to David.Of David Bruntonrsquos courage, he said: ldquoWords fail me.ldquoNo one asked him to jump in, yet he did.Garysaid: ldquoIt was such a wonderful letter for the station to receive and wersquore very grateful to Martin for getting in touch.Kieran ndash the son of Dunbar Leboat coxswain Gary Fairbairn ndash has received his pager a month after turning , the youngest age any" alt"East Lothian Courier: DUNBAR schoolboy Kieran Fairbairn has just become Scotlandrsquos youngest RNLI leboat volunteer crewmember.Kieran ndash the son of Dunbar Leboat coxswain Gary Fairbairn ndash has received his pager a month after turning , the youngest age any" class"editor-image"ldquoIt reminded the crew why we do what we do and brought home how proud we are of the crews that have served before us.As the RNLI launches its Christmas Appeal with the message that its volunteers are on call  , including Christmas Day, and it relies on the publicrsquos donations to keep its crews safe, Martin added: ldquoChristmas is special because the whole family meet together but they would not have been there at all without the courage and devotion of the crew of the Dunbar leboat.ldquoWhen you save a le, you donrsquot only save the past and the present. You save the future.

title: dunbar-man-pushed-woman-onto-hotel-bed-grabbed-neck
story: Ross Currie, of Castle Street, assaulted the woman by seizing her by the neck at the Hampton by Hilton hotel in the cityrsquos Fountainbridge.Currie uttered threats of violence before he pushed the woman onto a bed within a room at the hotel and began to restrict her breathing.He also placed a piece of clothing around her neck and restricted her breathing, all to the womanrsquos injury, at the Capital hotel on October .Currie admitted the attack on November  at Edinburgh Sherf Court and he was back in the dock for sentencing last Friday.Lawyer Phil Moore said that -year-old Currie had committed ldquoa serious offence but he has shown remorse.Sherf Adrian Cottam said: ldquoIt could have resulted in tragic consequences easily, even though Irsquom sure you didnrsquot mean that. Grabbing someone by the neck could result in death more easily than people think.ldquoUnpaid work is probably the most appropriate way of dealing with this. The report is favourable.Currie was sentenced to carry out  hours of unpaid work in the community over the next  months.

title: iain-gray-msp-best-worlds-argument
story: It was Mackintoshrsquos leadership, ably assisted by East Lothian Labour Party, that helped lead Scottish Labour towards support for a devolved Parliament and eventually to its delivery in .His words are carved into Parliament: ldquoPeople in Scotland want a degree of government for themselves. It is not beyond the wit of man to devise the institutions to meet these demands.The annual memorial lecture has been a fitting way of preserving his legacy. As a member of the lecture committee since , I have been very proud of the quality of speakers we have welcomed over the years.This yearrsquos lecture was due to take placetodaywith Sir Keir Starmer but has unfortunately had to be postponed for the moment. He plans to talk about the next phase of devolution and how it can work for Scotland and the rest of the UK. This is an important and timely debate.It is important to highlight that the constitutional question need not be binary ndash either the break-up of the UK offered by the SNP or the outdated centralisation of the Tories ndash but can instead focus on how we maximise the benefits of both devolution and Scotlandrsquos important role within the UK.The pandemic has shown how powerful devolution is, with Scotland controlling our public health response but still part of the economic response such as lsquofurloughrsquo made possible by the resources of the whole UK.This lsquobest of both worldsrsquo argument was at the heart of the pro-UK, pro-devolution message in  and I believe it still broadly reflects the view of the majority here in East Lothian.

title: tims-tales-trees-helping-hand
story: Itrsquos dark so early at this time that there is no daylight after teatime for us to enjoy our walks in a wood or by the sea, which is our tradition. Instead, we often do a night tour of the streets looking at the Christmas lights so many people have made the effort to display.Weekends have become our time to explore the woods and on Saturday the weather allowed us to venture out, after a few days of rain. We knew it would be muddy, and the trees bare of leaves, but we were on the hunt for holly and ivy to make our Christmas wreath and decorate the house.Itrsquos only when you venture into a wood in winter time that you fully appreciate the display of green that holly and ivy provides. They are naturersquos Christmas lights of colour, a gt of green in a sleeping wood that has lost most of its colour.I have written before about the mental health benefits of ldquoforest bathing, and for me regular visits to nature and walking amongst trees have always been a vital part of my mental wellbeing. And so as we ventured forth to a wood in East Lothian after days of being cooped up inside, I could feel my spirit lt.We arrived as the sun was already lowering in the winter sky. We had just two hours for our adventure and so we headed down into the wood.The sound of the Sauchet Water, which runs through the wood, reached us before we could see it. The rain of previous days had turned it into a tumbling river. I had hoped for this, as the sound of running water in naturersquos setting is so therapeutic. The kids stood by the bank, watching and listening to the river as it flowed past them, mesmerised by the sight and sound of it. I watched them as they stood together, saying nothing, but sharing the moment.After a few minutes, they came out of their trance and headed deeper into the wood to seek adventure. Our task was to find nice branches of holly and some ivy, but also to seek out the stories of the wood.And they found a story. A tree was in danger of falling because the river had eroded the bank. One side of its root system was exposed, with nothing to hold on to, so the tree was leaning towards the water, in danger of falling. But a neighbouring tree looked asit had come to the rescue. Its trunk was bending towards the tree in danger, giving it something to lean on.The kids called them the lsquoslipping treersquo and the lsquohelping treersquo. And when we looked at the roots of the two trees, we could see that they were, as my son described it, ldquoholding hands. I could see what he meant, for the roots of the lsquoslipping treersquo looked asthey were indeed holding onto the roots of the lsquohelping treersquo.Perhaps this was all their creative imagination, although there is clear scientic evidence that trees in a wood need each other and help each other in many dferent ways, especially via their underground root system. Andyou really look at trees, you will see the stories of their challenges, and of their resilience and survival in the face of them.The kids moved on in their adventure, but I paused for a moment at these two trees. There was a story here that spoke to me so directly in this most challenging of times: that we need to hold hands like this sometimes, by seeking and accepting the help of otherswe feel ourselves slipping. But also, we need to be able to recognise when someone  is quietly slipping and help them hold on.ldquoCome on, dad, we have found a perfect holly bush, the kids called out. My we Kate and I scrambled up the muddy slope to see, and sure enough they had.There is understandably a wealth of folklore and tradition about holly. Itrsquos said to be bad luck to cut the tree down but taking a small branch is OK, as long as you thank the tree.By this time, darkness was falling and the wood was feeling eerie, but in a good way. Part of exploring nature should be the enchantment of it, the mysteries it holds, and it being a bit scary at times is part of this.The bare branches of the trees silhouetted against a darkening sky was the perfect theatre to end our adventure, as the kids kept an eye out for faeries and malevolent magical creatures, which they knew would be kept at bay as long as they held onto their holly branches.We emerged from the wood into the dying light of the winterrsquos day, decorated with holly and ivy like figures from mythology ourselves.Such was our adventure last weekend. I felt so much better after the walk. Yes, it was the physical exercise and fresh air, but it was also the spiritual uplt a visit to the woods always gives, even in winter.And part of this,we choose to notice and listen, will be naturersquos stories, which can speak directly to us.

title: east-lothian-peeps-past-december-8-11-1995-1970-1920
story: A FAMOUS landmark atop North Berwick Law was in need of repair, reported the East Lothian Courier of December , .The whalersquos jawbone at the summit of North Berwick Law is to be repaired at a cost of about pound.The condition of the well-known local landmark has deteriorated over the decades and the townrsquos community councillors are keen to ensure it is saved for posterity.They approached the district council with their concerns and Macmerry-based specialists Ralph Plastics was contracted to do the job.They will restore the jawbone with fibre glass, and the protective railings around it will be repaired by Daw Engineering of Fenton Barns.Scaffolding will have to be used to carry out the work and the equipment will be taken up the hill by a tractor vehicle ndash a far cry from the mode of transport used to get the jawbone to the top in the s.lsquoWANTED,  beds for touring cyclistsrsquo was a headline in The Haddingtonshire Courier on December , .The Scottish Milk Race will again be passing through Dunbar on July , .The race took Dunbar into its tour of the country two years ago and caused great excitement.The only problem is where to put all the cyclists, race officials and representatives of the Milk Marketing Board when they arrive ndash  beds are needed.Co-operation is being asked for from local people and those living within a -mile radius of the town.MEANWHILE, power cuts hit the county.Scenes reminiscent of the wartime blackout were re-created in East Lothian this week when ious parts of the County were suddenly plunged into darkness by power cuts.Ironmongers, grocers and little general dealers shops found themselves almost besieged by customers clamouring for candles, paraffin and flashlight batteries.Those in the Tranent area were the first to feel the effects.A NEW bus service was introduced in Tranent, the first of its kind. The story made headlines in The Haddingtonshire Courier on December , .The motor bus service, inaugurated on Saturday by the Scottish Motor Traction Co., between Tranent and Edinburgh, was fully taken advantage of.On Saturday and Sunday, a considerable number of people preferred to travel direct to Edinburgh rather than undertake the long walk to Prestonpans station.On some of the journeys the motors were crowded, and on thejourney, on Sunday night, the service had to be duplicated.

title: town-centre-planned-new-town-blindwells-redesigned
story: The first residents of the new town of Blindwells are expected to move in by September next year.However, developers Hargreaves have revealed that the masterplan for the town, which will see an initial population in , new homes, has been revised to create a new shopping centre to fit demand.Speaking during a virtual public consultation on the detailed plans for the town centre, Iain Slater from Hargreaves, said that while they had initially been steeredby East Lothian Council planners towards a mini retail park and supermarket at he heart of the town, times had changed.He said: ldquoRetail has changed signicantly. While it was once all about going to the supermarket for a big shop, now it is more about deliveries and just going out to buy what you want for that evening.ldquoEast Lothian Council had guided us towards a mini retail park but it is not really sustainable, which is why we have gone back to the town centre.Mr Slater said that the developers had redrawn the town centre to create smaller shops with residential properties above them.Drawings produced during the webinar showed the new town centre based around a body of water to be named The Princes Loch at the north of the site.A market square and Mercat Cross appeared in artistrsquos impressions of the new high street, while boutique shops with four-storey-high buildings lined it, with ground floor shops and flats above.Proposed on the new high street are also a health centre, gym, family pub and restaurant, and cafes.And at the loch itself, there are plans for a potential cultural centre for the Battle of Prestonpans Trust, which has been in discussions with developers to mark the historic battle on the site.Developers also confirmed that initial hopes for a railway station in Blindwells had been ruled out by Network Rail, although it might be revisited when the town expands.East Lothian Councilrsquos Local Development Plan includes the initial delivery of Blindwells with a town centre, housing and new primary school.It also has a larger area of land to the east of the town ndash which sits between Prestonpans and Tranent ndashwhich has been dubbed Greater Blindwells for future expansion.Mr Slater said that as well as a possible rail station in Greater Blindwells, there was also the possibility of a new secondary school being built but added that this was still ldquoat a very early stage in plans for the future.Current education plans for children and young people moving into Blindwells will see primary-school children bussed to classes at neighbouring Cockenzie Primary School until completion of the new primary school, now due to be delivered on site for school session  .Secondary-school pupils will travel to Preston Lodge High School in Prestonpans.Concerns about the travel plans for school pupils, impact of the new town on the existing junctions on and off the A, and environmental impact were all raised by members of the public during the virtual consultation.Asked about the demographic planned for the new town, James Fraser from EMA Architects, which produced the masterplan, said the aim was to build a community.He said: ldquoIt is about trying to create a community, so all types of people will be welcome, from first-timebuyers to families and older people looking to downsize to a smaller home.The consultation remains open online until January  for comments atwww.blindwellsconsultation

title: reopening-swimming-pool-musselburgh-sports-centre-delayed
story: It was due to have reopened on Sunday, but "an issue during commissioning" has caused a delay.The pool has been closed since October  to enable a new replacement moving floor to be installed.This provides deeper or shallower depths to allow for dferent activities, like ing or childrens swimming.A spokesperson for enjoyleisure, which manages the facility, said: "The pool was closed to enable a new replacement moving floor to be installed, which is a major investment in the long-term sustainability of the swimming pool for the benefit of the community and a wide range of users."However, the work has encountered an issue during commissioning and will delay the reopening."We are working with the contractors to ensure that this is rectied as soon as possible."Whilst we are extremely disappointed in having to take this decision, the care of our customers is always our top priority and, while we know many people will be disappointed by the delay in reopening, we hope they will understand that it is for safety reasons."We are in the process of contacting everyone who has a booking that will be affected by this delay and will announce a new reopening date as soon as we can."

title: presents-left-prestonpans-bus-shelter-every-day-advent
story: Throughout this month, the anonymous kind souls behind the @PPansBus Shelter Twitter account are dropping off a gt each day for people to find and keep.Not only that but Pencaitland-based artist Lynn Fraser has painted seasonal pictures on the shelter to cheer up passers-by.Lynn told the Courier: ldquoIrsquove been following @PPansBusShelter on Twitter for a couple of years now and they just do these lovely things they leave tiny little figures sitting on little seats in the bus stop. Itrsquos just really quirky and it makes me smile.ldquoFor National Poetry Day, they put up poems on posters all round the bus shelter.ldquoBut I donrsquot know who they are!ldquoWhoever secretly runs the Twitter account leaves a little gt every day for anyone to find.ldquoI messaged them and said Irsquod like to paint Christmas scenes on the shelter, and they said go for it! So I did.A spokesperson for the Twitter account of the Northfield House bus shelter on Preston Road told the Courier: ldquoEach year the bus shelter is decorated for Christmas and, last year, small mystery packages were left in the run-up to Christmas.ldquoThis year, in conjunction with other bus stops on Twitter , Prestonpans Bus Shelter is taking part in #BusStopAdvent and small gtsare being left daily in the bus shelter.ldquoPeople who find a gt are encouraged to share on Twitter using the hashtag #BusStopAdvent.Lynn added: ldquoI love that they put out this little smile for the community. I just wanted to add to the fun.

title: lifeboat-crew-don-antlers-reindeer-run
story: More than a dozen members of Dunbarrsquos voluntary RNLI crew will pull on their wellies, waterproofs and lejackets. . . but not for a rescue.Instead, they are going to be clocking up the steps for a lsquoReindeer Runrsquo to raise money for the RNLI.Becs Millar, part of the inshore leboat crew, is among those stepping up to the challenge, which takes place on Saturday.She said: ldquoThe reindeer run is something the RNLI traditionally do.ldquoI took part in one about nine years ago over in Stirling and it is just something they like to do to as part of the fundraising.ldquoThis year, with Covid, we are just looking to raise funds as much as possible.ldquoOur donations are down signicantly, like others in the third sector.ldquoWe are going to do it in Dunbar up at Winterfield Park. We are planning to head up there so we can have the Land Rover on hand in case anybody does get called out. We will be doing laps round the field there.ldquoThere are some fitter lsquoreindeersrsquo in the pack and they may go and venture through the town.Becs, who has been a member of the Dunbar RNLI crew for six years, will be joined by about  fellow crew members in full kit, with helmets swapped for reindeer antlers, for the fundraising event at noon.Together, the volunteers are aiming to run, jog or walk a combined  kilometres ndash the equivalent distance of Dunbar Harbour to East Linton ndash while wearing full personal protective equipment .Coronavirus has had a major impact on groups across the country looking to fundraise, with events being called off due to social distancing restrictions.Dunbarrsquos RNLI has found it no dferent than many others, with a number of events being postponed.Becs, who recently started up her own personal trainer business, said: ldquoWersquove got a great fundraising team and traditionally we would have the leboat fete, which we do every year and is a massive fundraiser for the RNLI.ldquoThings like Strictly for the Leboats, which Veronica Davies [Dunbar RNLI fundraising committee chairwoman] is still looking to do at some point as well.ldquoTherersquos Dunbar Civic Week, when we would tend to be out on High Street, and the leboat fete, which is the main one.ldquoWe have not been able to go out and do talks in schools or with adult groups and most are very generous with donations to us.ldquoThe town are massive supporters, with us obviously being so close to the sea.ldquoWe are so lucky to have such great support in the community.To make a donation, go to reindeerrun.rnli.org fundraising dunbars-crew-follow-the-herd

title: gala-king-queen-light-wallyford-christmas
story: In keeping with Government guidance and restrictions, the ceremony took place at the Christmas tree next to the Wallyford Mining Memorial Stone at the St Clementrsquos housing estate.A floral tribute was laid at the mining memorial stone by Stuart Baxter, manager of Musselburgh Area Partnership, in remembrance of the  miners who lost their lives in Wallyford collieries from  to .A short pause of silence was also observed.Mr Baxter also presented Grace and Jamie with a gt from Wallyford Community Council, which organises the Christmas lights switch-on.Alister Hadden, community council chairman, expressed the grouprsquos thanks and appreciation to the area partnership for all its help and support throughout .Mr Hadden said: ldquoWe wish to thank all the clubs, groups, organisations, businesses and the community of Wallyford who contributed to the fundraiser for the Christmas lights to bring festive cheer to everyone who passes along Salters Road.ldquoWersquod also like to thank the lightways team who erected the lights, East Lothian Councilrsquos electricians Glen Kane and Andy McGregor, and site electrician Derrick Pender.

title: disused-phone-box-musselburgh-turned-floral-planter
story: Environment group Love Musselburgh C.I.C is set to give the phone box at Eskside West a new lease of le ndash as a floral planter.It will be repainted its original red colour and all the perspex window  have been removed. BT has also taken away the phone.Baskets will be put inside and the flowers will be allowed to grow out and over the empty windows.Melanie Roccio, of Love Musselburgh, said she was inspired to go ahead with the project after seeing a phone box in Tranent that was transformed by the Blooming Belters team.She contacted the Musselburgh-based CHANGES Community Health Project to askit would lsquoadoptrsquo the phone box from BT and allow Love Musselburgh to convert it into a planter.She said: ldquoAs a community interest company, we were unfortunately not eligible to apply, andnobody adopted it, it was going to be removed.CHANGES duly obliged and lsquoadoptedrsquo the phone box.Melanie said: ldquoI askedanybody could donate their time or equipment to power wash the kiosk for us.ldquoIt had been used as a toilet for a while and needed a really good clean.ldquoDanny Nuttall, from Cowan Professional Cleaning Services, was happy to help. He came along, spending loads of time making sure it was safe to work on.ldquoMyself and my friend Steve Croasdale have spent some time sanding and prepping the phonebox and we will use paint kindly donated by Hamill Decorating Services, although wersquoll need to wait for better weather.ldquoSeveral residents of West Holmes Gardens are members of Love Musselburgh, having signed up to our Adopt a Street campaign.ldquoWith the phonebox being just around the corner from them, they generously donated pound to put towards the cost of the conversion to a planter. It was completely unexpected and very much appreciated.Melanie added: ldquoWersquove also had lots of offers of help donations of materials from local residents, businesses and organisations, and would like to thank them all.ldquoWe hope to start planting in early spring and would be grateful for any green-fingered volunteers who could help us with the ongoing care of the flowers.Since BT launched its Adopt a Kiosk scheme, more than , communities across the UK have seized the opportunity to transform local phone boxes that had little or no usage.The growth of the mobile phone industry has seen phone box usage fall dramatically. Nearly half the phone boxes in the UK have been removed, but there are still about , red phone boxes which can be adopted.The Adopt a Kiosk scheme has been successful in transforming unused payphone kiosks and preserves their heritage, particularly in rural locations. It costs pound to adopt a phone box.

title: new-community-pantry-opens-tranent-help-people-need
story: Based in the Volunteer Centre East Lothianoffice on High Street, the new pantry aims to ldquocomplement East Lothian Foodbank ndash which is also based in the town ndash by providing food and essentials to those in need.Those who use the pantry will have access both to public donations and also to surplus supermarket food from Fareshare.Both fresh and frozen items are available, alongside dried food and toiletries.Launched on Monday, November , the community-run pantry is free, open to all and no referrals are needed. It is open Monday-Friday, .am-noon.It is overseen by VCEL, as well as the Pennypit Trustrsquos Fundamental Foods team and Farsquoside Area Partnership.VCEL said that the pantry would help those in need or who were financially struggling to reduce their shopping bills and allow them to free up money for other essentials, allowing those on tight budgets to let their money stretch further ndash something it said was especially helpful in the current climate.Both the Pennypit Trust, which set up the pantry, and VCEL have seen an increase in demand for crisis food support since the coronavirus pandemic started.Carrie Richmond, from Fundamental Foods, said: ldquoIt has been a dficult time for everyone, many peoplersquos household budgets are under pressure, and Covid- has made pressures on households, especially low-income households, even greater. The pandemic has shown that local pantries are rapidly emerging in response.ldquoThis pantry will complement the work of the local foodbank and can be a useful stepping stone, helping people reduce their food costs, feed themselves or their families, and keep more money in the household to pay other bills.ldquoIt is stocked with a iety of food donated by the local community and uses surplus food from supermarkets such as Aldi and Farmfoods.ldquoIt is a positive legacy from the emergency food hub that was set up at St Martinrsquos Church Hall during lockdown.ldquoWe are extremely grateful to the community for their generous donations, especially Bisset  Steedman for a brand-new fridge freezer, East Lothian Foodbank, VCEL for providing a welcoming space for the pantry and also Farsquoside Community Kitchenfor providing fresh, homecooked meals.Maureen Allan, chief officer at VCEL, said: ldquoIt is a great privilege to work with the Pennypit Trust on this fantastic initiative.ldquoThe community pantry is open to everyone in our community and we look forward to opening our building to more initiatives like this and to the communities in East Lothian.Those at the pantry are now appealing for donations as stocks are running low, with dried and tinned food items, toiletries and utility items all welcome. Examples of food items that can be donated include tinned fruit and vegetables, lentils, cooking oils, longle milk, sugar, coffee, biscuits, jam, soup, fruit juice, tinned meals, cooking sauces, baby food and formula, fruit juice, and dog and cat food.Toiletry and cleaning products such as toilet roll, wipes, washing powder, cleaning products, hair and body care, deodorant, toothbrushes and toothpaste are also welcome.The pantry has a fridge and freezer so items such as milk, cheese, yogurts, meat products and other frozen goods can also be donated. Donations of carrier bags are also appreciated.Those wishing to make cash donations can do so the money will go towards the running of the pantry.Those with any questions or wanting to offer their support are asked to call  .

title: unusual-fox-rocks-sighting-dunbar
story: Debbie Adamson was strolling on the coastal path above the clfs at Winterfield last Thursday when she spotted the creature lying still on rocks offshore.Debbie said: ldquoIrsquom originally from Africa, so Irsquom used to game viewing, and I saw something that looked out of place on the rocks but it was quite far out and I was worried that it was a dog. I didnrsquot even think it would be a fox, to be honest.Debbie took some shots with the camera on her phone and sent them to the Coastguard, who confirmed it was a fox and said they could not attend.Debbie said: ldquoIt was on the rocks in the shallows, which would have been a great risk to the Coastguard vessel.ldquoAnother lady who was passing had a telescope, and she had a look at it and confirmed it was alive.But the fox wasnrsquot moving, and Debbie said she and the other woman watched as the tide rose and half-covered the animal.ldquoThe tide was coming in, and the fox could have moved higher up the rock but it didnrsquot, she said. ldquoIts tail started floating and the woman with the telescope wanted to leave because we were both pretty convinced it wasnrsquot going to have a happy ending.But, said Debbie, as the water reached midway up the crafty creaturersquos back, ldquoit just swam.She added: ldquoI expected it to go to one of the other rocks because there were other rocks still above water, but it didnrsquot ndash it just made a beeline for the shore.Debbie and dog Tamba watched as the plucky fox swam m to dry land.Debbie, who has lived near Dunbarrsquos Winterfield Park for seven years said: ldquoIt swam really fast. I couldnrsquot believe how quickly it could swim.ldquoI tried to see what happened when it finally got to shore but it disappeared pretty quickly.ldquoThere were a couple of people walking past and I was like, therersquos a fox on the rocks! I felt like Dr Seuss!A spokesperson for East Lothian Councilrsquos Countryside Rangers said: ldquoItrsquos possible that the fox was foraging on the shore and spotted something of interest. Alternatively, it may have been spooked by something on dry land.

title: coronavirus-scotlands-self-isolation-period-dropped-14-10-days
story: The Scottish Government has announced that the self-isolation period forinternationaltravellers and positive contacts will be reduced from the current  days to  days.Currently, anyone inScotlandwho tests positive for Covid- should self-isolate for  days but close contacts should quarantine for  days.The move comes after the four UK chief medical officersagreed the latest evidence allows them to be confident that self-isolation of just  days will be sufficient to suppress the spread of the virus.When does the new rule come into force The new rulewill come into action from Monday.It means that anyone who has been contacted through Test and Protect, including through thecoronavirusapp, or their health board, and told to self-isolate, should do so for  days, instead of .Who  does the rules apply to A close contact - whichincludes members of the same household who test positive for the virus ndash who will now only need to self-isolate for  days.Anyone who is required to self-isolate after arriving from Scotland from certain overseas countries will also be able to stop self-isolating after  days.Anyone who is a ing traveller or who has been identied as a contact of a case and is on day ,, or  of an existing -day isolation period on Monday can end their isolation on Monday .What has the Scottish Government said HealthSecretary Jeane Freeman said: ldquoSelf-isolation, both for contacts identied by Test and Protect and through the foreign travel quarantine requirements, is critical to protecting people and reducing the spread of Covid-.ldquoFollowing their review of the latest evidence and having considered the joint recommendation of UK CMOs from all four nations, we have agreed to reduce the required isolation period from  to  days.ldquoWhile self-isolation may be for a shorter period, it remains vital that everyone who is required to do so remains at their home or other named address for this time. Only by doing this can we break the chain of transmission of the virus, protect the NHS and save lives.Does it apply to the rest of the UK The change to  days will also apply in England and Northern Ireland from Monday and it already applies in Wales.In a joint statement, the four UK CMOs said: ldquoSelf-isolation is essential to reducing the spread of Covid as it breaks the chains of transmission.ldquoAfter reviewing the evidence, we are now confident that we can reduce the number of days that contacts self-isolate from  days to  days. People whofrom countries which are not on thetravelcorridor list should also self-isolate for  days instead of  days.ldquoPeople who test positive should continue to self-isolate for  days from onset of symptoms or  days from point of taking a positive testasymptomatic. We urge everyone to self-isolate when appropriate, it will save lives.

title: bird-flu-scotland-spot-avian-influenza-safety-measures-ramped
story: The Chief Veterinary Officers of Scotland, England and Wales agreed on the new measures, which came into force today, which will protect wild birds and poultry following cases of the ldquohighly infectious Avian influenza illness in both populations.From today, it will be a legal requirement for all bird keepers to keep their flocks indoors and to follow biosecurity measures to limit the spread and eradicate the disease.Why are we talking about it now It comes as the Scottish Government announced an examination into the deaths of three swans in Clackmannanshire over disease fears.And on Friday, avian flu was confirmed in rearing turkeys at a premises near Attleborough in Norfolk, marking eight cases in captive birds in England.Cases of the disease have also been detected in wild birds.Public Health England has said the risk to the public from the virus was ldquovery low, and food standards agencies also said it does not impact the consumption of poultry products.Last month, restrictions were declared to prevent the spread of the virus as Scotland, England and Wales were made an Avian Influenza Prevention Zone .This means that poultry and captive bird keepers must take additional steps such as disinfecting equipment, vehicles and clothing, changing clothing and footwear before entering enclosures and limiting access to non-essential people.Housing measures are in force as of today -  Dec. You must house your birds to protect them from #AvianInfluenza. Birds like #Ducks  #Geese that cannot be easily housed must be kept in netted enclosed areas. See Scotlandrsquos declaration https:t.co XysTYvGyQ @RuralMattersSG pic cePuUsgZHow to spot bird flu Avian influenza viruses can be classied according to their ability to cause severe disease as either highly pathogenic or low pathogenic.Low pathogenic bird flu is often dficult to detect, with very few clinical signs.According to the Scottish Government, an infected flock might show signs of respiratory distress, diarrhoea, or a drop in egg production.Highly pathogenic avian influenza will often form symptoms more suddenly, with affected birds developing swollen heads, a blue colouration of the comb and wattles, respiratory distress, diarrhoea, and a signicant drop in egg production.The Scottish Government guidance saysyou are suspicious your flock has any form of avian influenza you must contact your local animal health office immediately.What to doyou find a dead or sick wild birdAccording to Scottish Government guidance, wild birds can carry several diseases that are infectious to people, so do not touch or pick up any dead or visibly sick birds that you find.If you find a single dead bird of prey, gull or wildfowl species , or find five or more birds of any other species in the same location and at the same time, you should report these incidents to Defrarsquos national telephone helpline .How is bird flu spread The disease spreads from bird to bird by direct contact or through contaminated body fluids and faeces. It can also be spread by contaminated feed and water or by dirty vehicles, clothing and footwear.The avian influenza virus changes frequently, creating new strains, and there is a constant risk that one of the new strains may spread easily among people. But there is no evidence that any recent strain of avian influenza has been able to spread directly between people.Avian influenza is an airborne disease. It can also be spread by wild birds and rodents whose movements change in response to flooding.How can I find out more Full details are available on the Scottish Government website here.

story: Cases have been recorded at Musselburgh Grammar School, North Berwick High School, Preston Lodge High School in Prestonpans, and Ross High School in Tranent.In North Berwick High, Preston Lodge and Ross High, a single person in all three schools has been diagnosed with Covid-, while at Musselburgh Grammar "a small number of people from the school" have tested positive.In all four cases, close contacts of those who have tested positive for coronavirus have been contacted and told to self-isolate ndash all others should still attend school as normal, except at Musselburgh Grammar School, where S and S pupils have been told to learn from home for the remainder of term other pupils at Musselburgh Grammar should still attend the school.A message sent today to parents and carers of pupils at all four schools said: "We have been working closely with NHS Lothian Health Protection Team and following all national guidance."A number of people have now been contacted because they have been in close and sustained contact with the case and the tracking process is now complete."These contacts will need to self-isolate and appropriate guidance and advice has been given."If you have not been contacted directly to tell you your child is a close contact, then your child should attend school as normalthey are well."Enhanced cleaning and infection control measures are in place in line with national guidance. title: scottish-open-returning-renaissance-club-third-year
story: The Aberdeen Standard Investments Scottish Open will tee off at The Renaissance Club on July  as the final tournament ahead of the th Open, which takes place at Royal St Georgersquos Golf Club in Kent.It is the fourth year in a row that the prestigious tournament has been held in East Lothian, with Brandon Stone winning at Gullane Golf Club in .Bernd Wiesberger lted the trophy last year at The Renaissance Club, near Dirleton, before Aaron Rai was crowned the winner at the same venue following a play-off with Tommy Fleetwood in October.The tournament had been due to be played in July but was pushed back due to the coronavirus pandemic.Unfortunately, this years competition was held behind closed doors due to the ongoing social restrictions.An international field of top golfers is again expected to take to the fairways at The Renaissance Club next summer.Provost John McMillan, the local authorityrsquos spokesman for tourism and economic development, described the announcement as a ldquoa real reward for both The Renaissance Club and East Lothianrsquos golf clubs as a whole.He said: ldquoIt is delightful news.ldquoWe hoped it would come back and letrsquos hope it will come back in all its glory and people come back to the best stretch of golf courses in the world.

title: senior-pupils-musselburgh-grammar-school-work-home-rest-term
story: The school took the decision to ask all S and S pupils to work from home last week following a number of positive Covid- cases.Last Friday, it was agreed to extend the home learning period until Tuesday of this week when it was reviewed.And in the latest update, Colin Gerrie, headteacher, told parents: "The decision has now been made for S  to continue with blended learning until the end of term and that S  students willto school when we reopen in January."This precautionary measure continues to be required to protect our school community without compromising the education of our the only assessment opportunity, and, in line with other schools, we will have further assessments in February March."The cancellation of the SQA exams requires that teachers gather a range of evidence to support grades and the January prelims are only one of these pieces of evidence."A detailed letter on school-based assessments will be issued to parents and students on Friday."Our staff support and cooperation on this matter."

store leases.He will hope to save as many as  stores and , jobs.The firm announced the news in June.:Monsoon enters administration threatening over  job lossesQuizCity locations:Buchanan Street, St
